climbs.name: Hilti Hotel
climbs.fa: S. Cameron, G. Diduck, A. Mcleod.  (1991)

content.description:
By far best 5.10 sport pitch in Jasper, if not the entire Canadian Rockies, a true classic.  Long, sustained, and memorable.  Perfect incut jugs, sidepulls, and a spectacular position overlooking Cavell Lake make this a must do climb. 
  
 The route is sustained and gently overhanging the whole way, good choice of rests and quick climbing will keep the pump at bay and help with the onsight. 
  
 Best to climb here on a hot day.

The obvious orange wall to the right of Stilgars Corner.
12 bolts to 3 bolt anchor.  Warning 60m will not reach the ground! 70 m may just barely, use your judgement when lowering.

Climb to a high first bolt, which you may want to stick clip. Cruise through very easy terrain to your second bolt, from here, the climb gets progressively steeper and harder!

Holds are thin up high!

Tie knots in on rap, 70 m rope required. 



Identify Stilgar's corner/ Hilti Hotel- the prominent left facing, orange corner. This is the bolt line just to the right on the grey face

13 bolts, rap ring + bolt

An awesome 4 or 5 pitch route with bolted anchors and options for variation. This route is on mostly very good quartzite and other than the first pitch, takes gear well.  P1: Start up an obvious ramp that angles up/right towards the main corner system. 5.5R, 55m P2: Continue angling up and right towards the corner; a two-bolt anchor is just below and right of crux pitch. 5.6, 30m P3: The crux pitch starts up the left facing corner until it shuts. Find thin face holds to get you up and left to another steep and elegant finger/hand crack and layback corner. Once topping out the second corner, head up and left 5m to a two bolt anchor. 10a, 30m P4: * 3 variations exist for the next pitch -Option 1: Head up and right for 2 more pitches of 5.9(40m), and 5.8(30m).  Two bolts are visible from the belay.   -Option 2:The main line follows very fun but occasionally hollow cracks/flakes on the left wall of the dihedral, close to the corner 5.9(60m) -Oprion 3: Head up the corner to an obvious finger crack left of the main line. This steep and continuous crack eventually slams shut over lower angled terrain until opening up again to the right as a wide crack that thins back down to fingers. 10a, grade not confirmed (55m) Descent: Rappel route in three 55m rappels. The upper corner is easily visible from the parking lot. It is probably the biggest corner system on the wall (do not confuse with another large corner system just left of the correct route). Find the right angles ramp that leads up to the steep corner. -Doubles to 3"
-2 ropes
-Lots of slings (long pitches)

An amazing face/slab climb on stellar rock. Start by traversing to the right to gain the ledge and your first bolt before leaving the deck. Follow 37 m of uninterrupted, sustained but not hard climbing!

With minimal shenanigans you can get off of this climb safely with a 70 m rope. Tie your knots! If you're concerned, you can pendulum over to the "Window in Your Heart" anchors just a few meters down and to the left of the Majestic Elegance anchors, then rap.  



Identify Stilgar's corner/Hilti Hotel- the prominent orange corner. This is the first bolt line to the left of the corner (~5 m)

14 bolts, rap rings

Follow a crack system up and left through black rock to the base of a shallow left facing orange dihedral. Clip a fixed angle and climb up past some flakes. Where the corner steepens move right (there's an old fixed knifeblade here) into another shallow left facing dihedral to the anchors.

Start in the same spot as Stilgar's Corner. The anchors are visible from the ground.
Single rack to #3 C4. The lower part of the route protects reasonably well, up higher it is a bit runout.

A beautiful corner with excellent stemming moves.  The first pitch is the best and has the crux, the second is easier but worth it.

Far right side of the Dune wall, this route defines this sector.
Gear to 3.5"  Bolted belays with rap rings.  Use 2 ropes to rap off.

So you walked out to Dune Wall to climb the highly rated sport climbs and you're super excited. You're walking along the base of the cliff, you see an orange corner and just to the left of it, a ledge that you can scramble up onto to clip a bolt. At this point, you should make sure that orange corner is in fact Stilgar's Corner, and not just another, much less prominent corner like the one next to this climb. 

Anyway- scramble up (low fifth) to a small ledge, clipping a bolt on your left. Old school horizontal hanger with a rusted out 1/2" head. Climb up lichen covered slab clipping a pin along the way to a wet/mossy pseudo ledge under a small roof. High clip a knife blade, turn the roof on very dodgy rock (careful not to pull the loose plate onto your belayer!), clip one more knife blade and pull up onto a grassy ledge with a two bolt anchor with biners. I strongly recommend rapping; it is in your best interest to minimize the amount of weight you put on the very rusty bolts! 



Just left of a not so prominent orange corner, right of the very low roof feature.

1 scary bolt, 3 pins, 2 scary bolt anchor

An exceptional rock buttress at the Base of Mount Sorrow, next to Mount Edith Cavell. This is a quiet area, with exceptionally high quality routes on perfect quartzite. The rock is very similiar to back of the lake, or Red Rocks desert climbing as well. You climb mostly on incut features, using cracks or bolts for protection.

In addition to the 3 stellar sport climbs, there are numerous multi-pitch (up to 5 pitches) climbs on this wall.

The season is short! July to mid-September and it can snow at any time of the year.
